DataElement.preferredName: Gamma Knife And/Or Radiation Surgery Administered Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indicator that describes whether or not gamma knife and/or radiosurgery radiation was administered.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Gamma Knife And/Or Radiation Surgery Administered
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Radiation therapy in which high-energy rays are aimed at a tumor from many angles in a single treatment session._Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid._A radiation therapy technique that delivers radiation directly to the tumor while sparing the healthy tissue.Also called radiation surgery and stereotactic external beam irradiation._The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Radiation therapy in which high-energy rays are aimed at a tumor from many angles in a single treatment session.:Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options:A radiation therapy technique that delivers radiation directly to the tumor while sparing the healthy tissue. Also called radiation surgery and stereotactic external beam irradiation.

Concepts.definition: A treatment using gamma rays, a type of high-energy radiation that can be tightly focused on small tumors or other lesions in the head or neck, so very little normal tissue receives radiation. The gamma rays are aimed at the tumor from many different angles at once, and deliver a large dose of radiation exactly to the tumor in one treatment session. This procedure is a type of stereotactic radiosurgery. Gamma Knife therapy is not a knife and is not surgery. Gamma Knife is a registered trademark of Elekta Instruments, Inc.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.
A surgical procedure to treat cancer cells that use high energy beams.
The act of having given something (e.g., a medication or test).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).
